Let $h_A$, $h_B$, and $h_C$ be the altitudes from vertices $A$, $B$, and $C$, respectively.

$Area(\triangle ACP) = \frac{1}{2} \times CP \times h_{C_P}$
$Area(\triangle BCP) = \frac{1}{2} \times AP \times h_{A_P}$

Similarly, for $\triangle ABP$ to have greater area than $\triangle BCP$, we need $AP \times h_A > CP \times h_C$.
The given conditions are equivalent to the condition that $P$ lies inside the region which is the intersection of the three regions where $Area(\triangle ABP) > Area(\triangle ACP)$, $Area(\triangle ABP) > Area(\triangle BCP)$, and $Area(\triangle ACP) > Area(\triangle BCP)$.
The region satisfying $Area(\triangle ABP) > Area(\triangle ACP)$ is the region in the interior of $\triangle ABC$ closer to $B$ than to $C$. This is a region on one side of the median from $A$ to $BC$.
The region satisfying $Area(\triangle ABP) > Area(\triangle BCP)$ is the region in the interior of $\triangle ABC$ closer to $A$ than to $C$. This is a region on one side of the median from $B$ to $AC$.
The region satisfying $Area(\triangle ACP) > Area(\triangle BCP)$ is the region in the interior of $\triangle ABC$ closer to $C$ than to $B$. This is a region on one side of the median from $A$ to $BC$.

The probability that $P$ lies in this region is $\frac{1/3}{1} = \frac{1}{3}$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{1/3}$
